headline: The evolution of Basketball in San Sebastian
text: How has a sport created in America impacted the Basque Country?

headline: Club Atlético San Sebastian is founded
text: The club was founded in 1958 by Josean Gasca together with a group of basketball players, some athletes and swimmers. Others were added to the first three sports sections of the club until reaching the current 12. One of the peculiarities of the club is its strong sports character and the fact that it does not have or has ever had a football section.

headline: Askatuak is created
text: Josean Gasca was the founder of Askatuak, coach, pioneer and promoter of basketball in the city of San Sebastián. Gasca had been the founder in 1958 of Club Atlético San Sebastián, a sports club in which basketball was the founding section of the Club and therefore played a predominant role in its beginnings. Atlético San Sebastián under the sports leadership of Gasca reached the First Division of the Spanish Basketball League in 1967, but after 3 seasons in the elite, the team ended up relegating and in 1973 the basketball section of Atlético San Sebastián was dismantled , after Gasca himself confronted the club's management, which did not share Gasca's idea of ​​professionalizing the basketball section of Atlético Sn.Sn.
mediaCredit: Archivo FEB. Josean Gasca impulsor y padre de la ACB en 1982

headline: Creation of Liga ACB
text: The competition was founded as the ACB Primera División on 1983 following the decision of clubs in the Liga Nacional, founded in 1957, to break away from the Spanish Basketball Federation and professionalize the league.

headline: GBC is created
text: In May 2001 a group of former players, coaches and businessmen linked to basketball convinced Miguel Santos to lead a basketball project in Gipuzkoa. GBC was born. GBC started competing in LEB 2, third tier. After a first season where the club finished in 11th position out of sixteen teams, it ceased in activity until 2004, when it came back to LEB 2. In the 2004–05 LEB 2 season, despite finishing in the second position of the regular season, Gipuzkoa BC was eliminated in the quarterfinals of the promotion playoffs by Ciudad de La Laguna. After this come back to competition, Gipuzkoa BC bought the place in Liga LEB, second tier, to CB Ciudad de Algeciras.

headline: GBC get promotion to ACB
text: Bruesa GBC only needed one season in LEB to achieve promotion Liga ACB. The team finished the regular season in the sixth position but performed a perfect playoff (7–0) to win the league.
mediaCredit: Gipuzkoa Basket (YouTube). GBC Canasta Ascenso Temp. 05/06

headline: GBC Changes its name
text: GBC changes its name to San Sebastián Gipuzkoa Basket and starts to play at Illumbe arena. In its first ACB season, the club gets the second larger public influx in the league and the largest number of members in the ACB. It shows Gipuzkoa people's enthusiasm with basketball.

headline: Lagun Aro GBC
text: The team was renamed Lagun Aro GBC due to a sponsorship change, The Gipuzkoan insurance company Lagun Aro, which a few years earlier had sponsored Bilbao Basket took over the name of the team.

headline: History being made
text: During the 2011-2012 season, GBC achieved a significant milestone by winning the LEB Oro league. Their remarkable performance secured them promotion to the prestigious Liga ACB, the top-tier professional basketball league in Spain. While the team struggled to find consistent success, their participation in the Liga ACB marked a historic achievement for the club. Ultimately, Gipuzkoa Basket finished in 17th place out of 18 teams, entering the relegation zone. After competing in the play-offs, unfortunately, they were unable to secure their position and were ultimately relegated at the end of the season.

headline: Money problems
text: In 2013, GBC faced significant financial difficulties. Their governmental grant was severely cut, which led to a strain on their ability to compete and maintain their position in the LEB Oro league. The club had to navigate through the tough circumstances, seeking solutions to stabilize their finances and ensure their long-term viability. Overcoming these monetary obstacles became a crucial focus for Gipuzkoa Basket as they aimed to secure a stable financial foundation for the future of the club.

headline: Back to LEB
text: After three seasons as coach, Sito Alonso leaves GBC for Bilbao Basket. The club then signed the Catalan Jaume Ponsarnau. Several players from the previous season left as well, among others Jason Robinson, Raulzinho Neto, Jon Cortaberria or Javi Salgado. But the club managed to keep David Doblas, Will Hanley and signed players like Jordi Grimau, Taquan Dean, Jared Jordan or Ioann Iarochevitch. The season started badly, with 5 consecutive defeats. On matchday 6 they won their first match against MoraBanc Andorra. Since then, the team won several victories that allow it to have a good margin for relegation. However, starting on matchday 25, the team went back into a horrible streak, winning only 1 of the 10 remaining games. Despite staying out of relegation for much of the season and having key matches to seal their permanence, the team reaches the last day with options to drop. To save himself, he depended on himself, and his direct rival, Manresa, had to win on the court of the regular league champion, Real Madrid, who had not lost a home game that season in the league. However, the miracle happened. The GBC lost their game, and Manresa did the unthinkable and won at the home of undefeated local Real Madrid, condemning Gipuzkoa Basket to the third relegation in its history.

headline: Pandemic year
text: To start another season in the second state competition, the Argentine Marcelo Nicola was entrusted with the position of coach, and the squad was revolutionized again: Xabi Oroz was the only player who continued, while Johnny Dee, Alex Murphy, Lazar Mutić, Karamo Jawara, Mikel Motos, Mikel Úriz, Reed Timmer, Julen Olaizola, Davis Rozitis, Biram Faye and Adam Sollazzo. The team soon began to demonstrate its potential, especially defensively, and remained at the top along with Carramimbre CBC Valladolid, a team that would win the Princess Cup 55-62 on February 4, 2020, thus becoming the first team that would win this title playing away. The season had no ups and downs until the COVID-19 pandemic led to its suspension in March 2020. The season came to an end, without relegation and with the promotion of the first two, including the GBC. However, the ACB did not accept those two promotions, so the San Sebastian club had to resort to justice. In this way, on july 31st Gipuzkoa Basket was told by justice that they would play the following season in the highest state competition. The fact of practically achieving promotion in August seriously harmed the interests of Gipuzkoa Basket, which had to build a squad against the clock and with the resources it had due to the losses caused by the pandemic. The coach, the team's Gipuzkoan block and Johnny Dee were kept, and up to 8 signings were made. Despite the low quality of the squad, the team began the season with good games, although this illusion would not last long as the team began to lose its arms, achieving only 3 victories in the first round. An improvement early in the second round was not enough for the team to avoid permanence. On May 13, 2021, the relegation in the derby against TD Systems Baskonia was certified, with two games to go before the end of the season.
